item.title: Buy It Again Recommendation
item.description: Buy-it-again is a popular recommendation model in online retail. In this post we will cover a simple model proposed in Buy it again: Modeling repeat purchase recommendations that achieves good results despite its simplicity.

item.description: These are my notes for the lecture Networking with Purpose by Dr Peter Kelly I suggest you check it out if you have the time.

item.title: RMSE Assumptions
item.description: The Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) is a common loss function used in machine learning for regression tasks that measures the average distance between the predicted and true values. However, what implicit modeling assumptions are me making when we use such error to evaluate the model fit?

item.title: Galloping Search
item.description: Suppose we we have sorted array and we are interested in finding a particular element. There are a number of ways we can go about it.

item.title: Binary Representation of Negative Numbers
item.description: Many of you already know that to in computer systems, to represent the negative numbers we use what is known as 2’s complement. In this article I will try to explain where it came from.

item.title: The Luhn Formula
item.description: The Luhn formula is a simple checksum formula used for validating identification numbers. It is designed to protect against accidental errors in data entry but not malicious attacks. For example, on a website a user may enter a credit card number or ISBN and sometimes these numbers may be mistyped. One can then use the Luhn formula to determine if the entered number is a valid one.

item.title: K-means clustering
item.description: K-means is a clustering algorithm that is relatively old yet it still in use today because of its simplicity and power.

item.title: How to Speak
item.description: These are my notes for the lecture How To Speak by Patrick Winston. I suggest you check it out if you have the time.

item.title: Page Rank Algorithm
item.description: PageRank is an algorithm used to rank web pages in search engines results. It was named after, one of the founders of Google, Larry Page.

item.title: Value Rigidity
item.description: I was reading a book called The Passionate Programmer by Chad Fowler. The books talks about what it takes to create a remarkable career in software development. It is a very good read and if you haven’t read it yet I suggest you check it out. In this post I will try to one particular story that resonated with me.

item.title: The Naive Bayes Assumtion
item.description: The Naïve Bayes classifier is a popular machine learning algorithm. In this post we will discuss why it still works in practice even when the (naïve) conditional independence assumption is violated.

item.title: The Perceptron
item.description: The perceptron is a learning algorithm. A rather simple one yet surprising, it can acheive very good results as we will explore in this post.
